instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
I got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that someone else had messed with before. When connected to the charger, it shows 5v and 0.28a on all 4 ports. The board looks clean, with no signs of liquid damage or corrosion but someone ripped the keyboard connector and the right speaker connector off the board. Some of the pads for <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S_FAN_CONN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>GND_FAN</SIGNAL> were destroyed and <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground. Found that <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground inside the board right by the keyboard connector. I drilled a small hole in the board in this location and was able to clear the short, but it did not change anything. Still only getting 5v and 0.28a on all 4 ports. Can't find any other shorts.

I replaced the keyboard connector and the flex cable and I tried to do the T2 firmware restore on this computer, but it does not seem to connect correctly. Every time I connect this computer to the the other working macbook (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>), its comes up with a message in the top right corner of the screen that says "Cannot Use Thunderbolt Accessory". This error comes up no matter which port I connect it to. I did notice that when I connect the 2 macbooks together and connect the charger to this board, it show 20v and 0a instead, which I believe is DFU mode. The DFU icon never comes up in apple configurator though like it has for other macbooks I have fixed. Not sure if I have a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> issue or not. Here are some measures I took. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.28
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> - 3.37
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_T</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_X</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_TBT_X</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_TBT_T</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_TBT_X_SNS</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_TBT_T_SNS</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_PRIM</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 1.8
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> -  0.8
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 1.09
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PMU_RSLOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_OM_R</SIGNAL> - 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shows like it is not correctly controlled, pointing to T2 firmware issue.
However the consume of the board looks to high, with 0.28A.

Compare diode mode readings on all LDO outputs of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

Did you try the same USB-C/Thunderbolt cable used in other DFU recoveries?

Not tu much hope for a board maltrated in such way...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
I did watch the video that Louis recently posted on his channel about the T2 firmware restore process and in the video, his <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> was showing 5v 0.30A and the T2 firmware restore fixed it still. I did use the same cable that I have used for other T2 firmware restores and it worked fine. I also have another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> right now that I tried to boot into DFU mode using that same cable and that computer shows the DFU icon in apple configurator so the cable is not the issue. I compared values for the LDO lines of each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip and the values for <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> are slightly higher than then other 3 chips. Do you think I should replace <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and try the firmware restore again?

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.478
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_SX</SIGNAL> - 0.506
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.485
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.451
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.461

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.478
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_SX</SIGNAL> - 0.506
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.510
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.472
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.487

UB300:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.479
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_T_SX</SIGNAL> - 0.502
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.488
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.454
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.463

UB400:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.484
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_T_SX</SIGNAL> - 0.505
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.490
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 0.457
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.465

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
Should try replacing <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.
Usually fault chip has lower values, but is not normal to have one chip with such differencies; even values are higher.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message: I replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> with a new one and now the diode mode values are about the same as the others but I still have the same symptoms. I tried the T2 firmware restore again but got the same message about "Cannot Use Thunderbolt Accessory" when connecting this board to the other mac. I tried all 4 ports and another cable but still get the same error message.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
0.28A is way too high for hanging on 5V. There must be a short or low resistance on some rail somewhere. Another short in the board is very likely as you cannot just drill into a board and not expect to short other layers together.
PPBUS is also too low so SMC is probably not running, so SMC may be suspect too. With 0.28A flowing something may be getting warm. Feel the board with your lips or thermal cam if you have it.

Honestly I think this board is a time waster :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
Yea I think your right. I checked to see if anything was getting hot but could not feel anything. I left the board connected to the charger for a long time too. One thing I noticed is that when I touched the area around <CHIP>U6940</CHIP>, the amps dropped from 0.28 to 0.22 and it would stay like that until I unplugged the charger and plugged it back in. This only happens when I touched that area of the board but I did not feel anything hot. I checked for shorts around that area and did find some rails that seems to either be short or have low diode mode values around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. I removed some of the coils around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> to check which side the shorts are on and these are the rails I found to have low diode mode values.

<SIGNAL>PP0V82_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> - 0.016
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> - 0.024
PPVCCPRIMCORE_PRIM_REG - 0.060
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 0.005

Should I try injecting voltage into one or all of these lines or do you think this board is hopeless? I also connected the charger after removing the coils and its now shows 0.03A then goes up to 0.06A, then back to 0.03A.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
You've mentioned voltages around CPU and can have low values as normal.
You should compare them with a good working board.

Sincerely, I will not waste more time on this board...
